title: Tuesday, 2nd February, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

tinhat

Now look

I mention this hear cos I know one Rabble member bought a table last time we did this with Christies

PM

But guess we should press on

11:05 am
undefined
BE

So, it's not the best day to rattle the charity can.

BE

I don't imagine many of our readers are feeling richer this morning.

11:06 am
PM

Yeah, guess you are right\

BE

(Well, @FJP will be. But he's an evil shorter so doesn't count.)

BE

FTSE down 1.7% at pixel.

11:07 am
BE

Off a tonne, back below the psychologically whatever 6k level.

PM

Sheesh

BE

Do I have to do my "volatility clusters" routine again? Because I'm sure everyone's heard it already.

11:08 am
BE

Instead, let's turn direct to oil.

PM

Yeah

PM

sick of your bloody volatility clusters

11:08 am
PM

This is the worst it's been since the proper crisis days

BE

Ditto. But we can only use the material we have.

BE

And today we have BP's Biggest Annual Net Loss Ever!

11:09 am
BE

Or on a quarterly view: clean net income of $196m.

BE

Against a company-provided consensus of $730m

BE

That's down 89 per cent on Q3.

11:09 am
BE

Or if you prefer adjusted EBIT: $491m against a $1.5bn company-provided consensus.

PM

ok ok, i now understand why the stock 's been spanked

BE

And it's because upstream, mostly.

11:10 am
BE

Which was lossmaking.

BE

Lossmaking to the tune of $728m.

BE

Underlying operating cash flow looks okay though! It's down just 20% just at $5.9bn.

11:10 am
BE

But that's mostly attributable to a $3.6bn release of working capital.

BE

So ignore underlying operating cash flow.

BE

Now ...... Q4 is generally the most unpredictable one

11:11 am
BE

It's very difficult to guess how trading income turned out, for example.

PM

Clearly

BE

(Unless you're a weather forecaster, which oil analysts generally aren't.)

11:11 am
BE

.... or how much it'll be booking for the year end in exploration write-offs.

BE

($923m written off in the quarter. Which is half a Tullow Oil, if you prefer.)

BE

And -- as we've said numerous times -- the consensus can go very wrong indeed without the guiding hand of an Investor Relations department.

11:13 am
BE

Somewhere in the archive I've a column discussing this at length, but I can't find it immediately.

BE

So instead, let's note BP's slightly peculiar underperformance yesterday.

BE

As in:

11:13 am
BE

PM

hmmmmm

BE

White line's BP

11:13 am
BE

Green line's Shell B

BE

Yellow's Brent

BE

All normalised to 8am Monday.

11:14 am
BE

Basically, BP had already underperformed Shell and Brent by 4% before there was any news on the tape.

BE

So while today's result seems to have surprised the sellside, the buyside might've been a bit wiser.

PM

You calling for a Stewards here?

11:15 am
BE

No! I'd never call the stewards. I'm just placing today's fall into context. As in, on the back of another fall.

BE

So anyway. Q4 underlying EPS is 4p.

BE

2016 consensus EPS is nearly 18p.

11:15 am
BE

And -- correct me if I'm wrong, but my analysis suggests that four times four isn't 18.

BE

There's still a divi though!

BE

Against net debt increased from $25.6bn to $27.2bn in three months.

11:16 am
BE

Which, clearly, is unsustainable.

BE

Making the continuance of the divi either an option on the oil price, a gamble on management's ability to cut the right costs without damaging what's already woefully underpowered cashflow, or both.

BE

Barclays is okay with taking that gamble.

11:17 am
BE

That the macro environment remains challenging is not in question, but we continue to see BP as having a more material opportunity than most in the sector to reduce the cost base given a high starting point. On this we are encouraged that BP has increased the savings it expects on controllable cash costs to $7bn, from the previous guidance of $6bn, much of which is coming from the need to simplify the business. As expected, BP also maintained the dividend in the quarter, reflecting its confidence around the ability of the company to balance sources and uses of cash. It is difficult to argue this is a good quarter for BP on the numbers alone, but we believe the key to BP's share price performance in the coming 12 months is continued evidence of its ability to control costs. With action already well underway, we continue to see BP as being able to differentiate itself on this metric. The shares are offering close to a 7.5% yield and over 50% potential upside to our 600p/sh NAV-based price target. We rate the stock Overweight.

PM

I can see where they are coming from.

PM

This is BP

11:18 am
PM

Medium term value

BE

There are worse ideas than buying BP and forgetting about it for two decades. But I'd only suggest that as an investment idea if you're able to forget about it for two decades.

BE

At the moment, it's not clear what shape BP needs to be to fit a market that's changed quite dramatically over the past 12 months.

11:21 am
PM

Actually, if you'd bought it 20 years ago you'd just and so have got your money back

PM

Ignoring dividends

BE

Yup. And history tells us that only an optimist will be spending that implied yield of 7.6% before it's in the bank.

11:22 am
PM

(What Barc call was this? omg smile )

BE

Did I also note the Reserves Replacement Ratio?

PM

No you didnt

11:22 am
BE

61%.

BE

Which isn't a good sign, right? For your 20-year investment case.

BE

Anyway, that's BP.

11:23 am
undefined
PM

Just on yields quickly -- par just dropped from Gary Paulin

PM

Further to our comments yesterday, which questioned the sustainability of some UK dividend payers, we add that Shell, one of the largest dividen payers in the FTSE, has had its debt rating cut to the lowest since S&P began coverage in 1990 and BP has been put on negative watch, not helped by them posting their lowest profit in 20 years and seeing their equity value falling -8%. While they commit to paying their dividend, they must do so (partly) by debt - an uncomfortable scenario given the uncertainty around oil prices/cashflows, which is core to the issue of sustainability. With this context we remain wedded to our Quality Cash Compounders thematic as all these stocks generate plenty of free-cash-flow and have long histories of compounding their cash returns at +double digit rates. Scarce resources in this environment. Of those in the basket we would highlight Sky, ITV, BT, IMT, BATS, RB/, WHM, and BRBY who all have decent dividends (greater than 3%) which are all well covered, and so, have room to grow. Our Bond Like Equity Basket is also a great source of sustainable dividend growth, and we highlight Admiral Group and Glaxo (report tomorrow) as two of our favouites. The best performer with the highest dividend is Morrison's. While not in these baskets, one of our highest conviction themes remains UK Housebuilders. Take Berkeley Group for instance, they have committed to pay you ~5.4% annually out until the end of 2021. Similar duration sovereigns yield you less than 1%. Buy BKG.

11:24 am
PM

Buy Berkeley Group says Aviate

undefined
PM

Got to do Home

11:25 am
PM

This is not quite a done deal -- or is it?

BE

Well, at the moment it's a one-fact story. There's an acre of press coverage, though your really don't need to read beyond the headline for most of it.

BE

Basically, it's a deal at 160p-ish.

11:26 am
BE

All the haggling was just haggling, with HOME shareholders hugely overplaying their hand which resulted in them looking a wee bit silly.

BE

Though I'm sure they won't mind much, given the 60-something per cent premium to the undisturbed price.

BE

So. In terms of structure, 0.321 New Sainsbury shares and 55p cash.

11:28 am
Home Retail Group PLC (HOME:LSE): Last: 153.00, up 0.1 (+0.07%), High: 155.00, Low: 147.00, Volume: 14.01m
PM

Were we surprised by how much paper is in the mix?

BE

Again, I guess this reflects Home shareholders sounding off then having to capitulate.

11:29 am
BE

None, I'd imagine, particularly want to own a grocer that's going to spend the next three years embroiled in a strategic project.

BE

They bought a chain of shops that sold cheap TVs and had a big debtor book.

BE

So, yes, there's likely to be a bit of flowback.

11:30 am
BE

Canaccord incoming.

BE

With the total all-in value of the offer some 20% below the 200p some shareholders
were cited as looking for from the bidder, a level at which the shares were indeed trading
a year ago, this therefore looks like a case of "possible" capitulation in our view by Home
Retail and its shareholders, especially as the Home Retail board "continues to believe in
the prospects for the standalone Company". More telling is its comment that it provides
an "attractive opportunity..for...shareholders...to receive a full valuation for their shares".
Given our fundamental valuation of 100p for Home Retail, this possible offer looks
an attractive opportunity for Home's shareholders to cash in their chips. Relative to
the 98.7p share price on 4 January, they will receive 82.8p in cash and an option via
Sainsbury paper (78.5p) to maintain an interest in Home's future - albeit with exposure
to the UK grocery sector and its current challenges.

BE

Home's shares are trading at a cal 16 PER of 16.4x falling to 15.0x. Sainsbury's base
offer for the rump (i.e. 133.5p or £1.1bn, post sale of Homebase) values this at a cal 16
PER of around 21.7x or almost a 45% premium to the wider sector. This is calculated on
the basis of backing out Homebase's earnings (3.22p) from the group EPS (9.35p

11:31 am
BE

And Barclays .....

BE

The price and the mix of cash / equity are consistent with recent media reports, while the £120mn of synergies are a little higher than some might have expected. Although double-digit EPS accretion (year three) is hard to ignore, Sainsbury is also taking on execution risk and a business with difficult track record. No new strategic information to change the minds of sceptical shareholders.

PM

hmm

11:32 am
BE

And Cantor.

BE

This possible offer from Sainsbury’s is less vulnerable to any higher cash offers but management will need to convince shareholders that the sales uplifts from Argos inserts can generate significant profits, implying the Argos retail and Financial Services operations can generate £150m of trading profit after central costs or c.4% trading margin by March 2019. However, there are £47m of annual one-off costs for three years and £140m of capital investment over three years that will result in a small cash inflow to March 2017.

BE

Easy to assume Sainsbury is overpaying here.

11:33 am
BE

And just because it's easy, it's not necessarily wrong.

Our ability to package our unique proprietary technology, including our equipment solution, for retail partners outside the UK through our Ocado Smart Platform is proving to be of great interest to a significant number of retailers. We expect to sign multiple deals in multiple territories in the medium term.

11:39 am
BE

(He might've just been hurt to be at the cricket. I would've been.)

BE

BE

Either that was untrue -- which rumours often are -- or that deal collapsed and everything's in the medium term again.

11:41 am
BE

But perhaps this is all too negative. Who can we turn to for a positive view?

BE

Ah. Goldman. Of course.

BE

Ocado reported FY15 results (November year-end) with revenues of £1,108
mn and EBITDA of £81.5 mn (+16.7% and +13.8% respectively yoy) in line
with with GSe/Bloomberg consensus of £1,115 mn and £81.6 mn. EBIT of
£21.4 mn was slightly below GS/consensus of £22.7 mn/£22.3 mn due to
£1.8 mn of impairment charges. Morrisons fees were £18.8 mn (+8.7%).
Despite retail gross margins down 40 bp, the Ocado.com business (ex
Morrisons) saw EBIT margin expansion of c40 bp (c20 bp excluding income
from landlord compensation), demonstrating operating leverage in the
core business, primarily driven by distribution costs.
Capital expenditure was £122 mn and net external debt was £7.5 mn.
CFC3 will go live shortly and CFC4 is scheduled to commence operations at
the end of 2017. MHE capital costs of £45 mn and £135 mn are unchanged.
On Smart Platform, the Group has updated its guidance and stated that it
expects to sign multiple deals in multiple territories in the medium term.
No deal is announced with this release, but Ocado stated that its
confidence in the quality of its commercial proposition to international
grocery retailers remains high.
For FY16, the Group expects capex of £150 mn and to continue growing
ahead of the online grocery market. It does not expect material capital
expenditures in 2016 for any Smart Platform deal signed.

11:41 am
BE

Underlying EBIT margin expansion at Ocado.com, despite the gross
margin pressures in the UK grocery sector, alongside strong sales growth,
underlines the quality of the core business. We still believe the Ocado
Smart Platform is a compelling solution for grocers looking to move online.

BE

INVESTMENT LIST MEMBERSHIP
Pan-Europe Buy List
Pan-Europe Conviction Buy List

BE

Merrill, meanwhile, says "stop taking about the medium term and bloody get on with it."

11:42 am
BE

We think the shares today provide an opportunity for those looking to leverage the
global online grocery theme and gain exposure to what we regard as a truly unique
business model. Though the entry of Amazon in the UK grocery market with its Pantry
service could be seen as another competitor and so a threat to Ocado, we still believe
that Ocado’s technology expertise is unique in the fresh/perishable area. Accordingly we
think its international licencing potential is the real long-term value driver for the stock
but we understand the market impatience in the absence of any agreement yet.

BE

Which is all we can say, really. The numbers are as guided. The vague talk last month of something happening with Amazon looks to just be talk, perhaps connected to the 20% short in this thing.

BE

So we wait. We wait, interminably, for the medium term.

Donald Tusk, European Council president, set the clock ticking for the decisive “Brexit” vote when he circulated to all 28 EU capitals the “new settlement” being offered to Mr Cameron. The paper — covering migration, protections for the City of London, sovereignty and competitiveness — forms the basis for the British deal Mr Tusk hopes to seal at a Brussels summit on February 18-19.

12:01 pm
BE

(Bloomberg) -- Gulf Keystone Petroleum Ltd. bondholders are
preparing for a potential debt restructuring after the oil
producer’s cash holdings fell below an alert-trigger level in
October, according to two people familiar with the matter.
GLG Partners, Sothic Capital Management and Taconic Capital
Advisors are among distressed-debt investors who have banded
together and hired Houlihan Lokey Inc. to advise them, said the
people, who asked not to be identified because the matter is
private.

BE

The bondholders are organizing as Gulf Keystone contends
with late payments from the Kurdistan Regional Government and
slumping oil prices. Notes issued by the company, which holds
licenses to export crude from the autonomous Kurdish region in
northern Iraq, are quoted near record lows.

BE

Based on precedent, what's the likely endgame here? And is that likely endgame positive or negative for equity holders?

12:02 pm
BE

Ah, hell. It's their money.

PM

Well, it promises to be just like Lonmin

PM

Clowns think it's good news that the stock gets diluted to hell

12:02 pm
PM

Let's see what happens

BE

Whatever. Have some Parento.

BE

Kurdish authorities yesterday announced it will base payments to the IOCs on
their contractual entitlements from January 2016 and onwards. The payments
will be made within 10 working days after month end. This replaces the monthly
USD 75m gross payments which have been paid since September 2015, and
improves the visibility on the timing and size of future export payments. The
payments will also now be more directly correlated to oil prices and production
volumes, creating a clearer incentive to invest and grow output. Importantly
(and as promised last year), KRG will put in place an additional 5% payment on
top of the contractual entitlements in order to start working on the companies’
receivables vs KRG. Further, KRG signalled that it will increase payments to allow
for quicker recovery of the receivables as soon as the oil price recovers.

12:03 pm
BE

We expect Gulf Keystone to receive monthly payments of about USD 10m net
(vs previously USD 12m) at the current Brent oil price of USD 35/bbl. The
company will at our estimates be able to make the April 2016 interest payment,
but have no buffer in case of unforeseen events. Driven by our expectations of a
recovery in global oil prices in H2’2016, the company should also be able to
make the October interest payment. This implies that the company will have
until early 2017 to find a long-term financing solution (USD 250m 1. lien share
pledge bond matures is April 2017). In our opinion, the further normalization of
the export payment situation in Kurdistan improves Gulf Keystone’s chances of
securing a partner at Shaikan to fund investments in production growth and
provide the company with much needed additional liquidity. However, in the
current low oil price environment we still question if this can be achieved in time
to avoid a debt restricting that could become highly dilutive for shareholders,
and maintain our Hold recommendation.
